The University has a very strict policy against plagiarism and particular care must
be taken to acknowledge the work and opinion of others.

Plagiarism takes several forms, the commonest being unacknowledged quotation
or close paraphrasing of other people's writing, amounting to the presentation of
other personsâ€™ thoughts or writings as one's own.

To acknowledge text from another source, place it in quotation marks, state that
you are quoting from another source and name the source in the surrounding
text or as a footnote. Keep such quotations below 200 words.

Acknowledge clearly the use of Al tools, and note (like any tool) the responsibility
for the final output (thesis, paper, report) rests with the author.

Plagiarism will be penalised; an extreme case may be classified as a dishonest
practice and can lead to expulsion.

When you start your studies, you will be required to sign a declaration that you
abide by the University's general regulations about plagiarism which can be found
in the University Calendar https://www.dur.ac.uk/university.calendar/), Volume 1,
General Regulations, Examinations, section VIII, section (4)

Be particularly careful when preparing your thesis of the regulations governing
plagiarism (appendix 3) and copyright. Remember your thesis is a published
document that will be in the public domain and as such must conform to
publication standards. This means that, for example, you should create your own
artwork, chemical formulae and diagrams whenever possible.

2025/7/28 02:30 Avoiding Plagiarism
If you have to reproduce published material then it should be properly attributed
and permission obtained (in advance) for its reproduction from the relevant
copyright holder. Unattributed reproduction of previously published material
constitutes plagiarism and could result in severe penalties.

Students should also be aware of the issues surrounding self-plagiarism. In
particular, no piece of work may be submitted for examination twice (for example
work arising from final year undergraduate projects and that carried out during
the period of postgraduate study).

Furthermore, it is unacceptable to submit the same piece of work for publication
in more than one place (e.g. two different journals).
